exercises.question: The company, ___ reputation is global, is opening a new branch here.
exercises.answer: whose
exercises.example_sentence: The company, whose reputation is global, is opening a new branch here.

exercises.question: Choose the formal causal linker: 'The flight was cancelled ___ the heavy fog.'
exercises.answer: due to
exercises.example_sentence: The flight was cancelled due to the heavy fog at the airport.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a formal relative clause.
exercises.answer: This is the process by which the product is made
exercises.example_sentence: This is the process by which the product is made in our factory.

exercises.question: Match the relative pronouns with their specific uses.
exercises.example_sentence: They introduced a system whereby employees can work from home.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'To whom it may concern, I am writing to express my interest.'
exercises.answer: To whom it may concern, I am writing to express my interest.
exercises.example_sentence: To whom it may concern, I am writing to express my interest in the position.

exercises.question: The project was delayed ___ account of technical difficulties.
exercises.answer: on
exercises.example_sentence: The project was delayed on account of technical difficulties with the server.

exercises.question: Which sentence is correctly structured using 'of which'?
options: He bought ten books, three of which were mysteries.
He bought ten books, three of whose were mysteries.
He bought ten books, three of them which were mysteries.
exercises.answer: He bought ten books, three of which were mysteries.
exercises.example_sentence: He bought ten books, three of which were mysteries.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use 'owing to'.
exercises.answer: Owing to his illness he missed the exam
exercises.example_sentence: Owing to his illness, he missed the final exam last week.

exercises.question: Match the causal linkers to their grammatical follow-up.
exercises.example_sentence: Since it was raining, we stayed inside.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The man with whom I was speaking is the director.'
exercises.answer: The man with whom I was speaking is the director.
exercises.example_sentence: The man with whom I was speaking is the director of the company.

exercises.question: It was a mistake ___ I will always regret.
exercises.answer: for which
exercises.example_sentence: It was a mistake for which I will always regret.

exercises.question: Choose the correct sentence to describe a tool: 'The software...'
options: The software, by means of which we analyze data, is new.
The software, whose we analyze data, is new.
The software, by which we analyze data with, is new.
exercises.answer: The software, by means of which we analyze data, is new.
exercises.hint: Using 'by means of which' for tools/methods.
exercises.example_sentence: The software, by means of which we analyze data, is new.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence about a person's property.
exercises.answer: The neighbor whose car was stolen is very upset
exercises.example_sentence: The neighbor whose car was stolen is very upset about the incident.

exercises.question: Match the linker with its formal alternative.
exercises.example_sentence: The road was closed; consequently, we had to take a detour.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Owing to a lack of interest, the course has been cancelled.'
exercises.answer: Owing to a lack of interest, the course has been cancelled.
exercises.example_sentence: Owing to a lack of interest, the course has been cancelled.

exercises.question: The reason ___ he left early remains a mystery.
exercises.answer: why
exercises.example_sentence: The reason why he left early remains a mystery to all of us.

exercises.question: Which relative clause is non-defining? (Adds extra, non-essential info).
options: My brother, who lives in London, is a doctor.
The man who lives next door is a doctor.
The car that is parked outside is mine.
exercises.answer: My brother, who lives in London, is a doctor.
exercises.hint: Uses commas and provides extra info.
exercises.example_sentence: My brother, who lives in London, is a doctor.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use 'due to the fact that'.
exercises.answer: He failed due to the fact that he didn't study
exercises.example_sentence: He failed the test due to the fact that he didn't study at all.

exercises.question: The hotel, the rooms ___ were very small, was quite expensive.
exercises.answer: of which
exercises.example_sentence: The hotel, the rooms of which were very small, was quite expensive.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'They have created a culture whereby everyone feels valued.'
exercises.answer: They have created a culture whereby everyone feels valued.
exercises.example_sentence: They have created a culture whereby everyone feels valued and respected.

exercises.question: ___ I really need is a long holiday in the sun.
exercises.answer: What
exercises.example_sentence: What I really need is a long holiday in the sun to recover from work.

exercises.question: Choose the correct cleft sentence for emphasizing the person: 'John broke the window.'
options: It was John who broke the window.
What John did was break the window.
The window was broken by John.
exercises.answer: It was John who broke the window.
exercises.example_sentence: It was John who broke the window, not his brother.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence emphasizing a time.
exercises.answer: It wasn't until I got home that I realized
exercises.hint: Emphasis on the delay of an action.
exercises.example_sentence: It wasn't until I got home that I realized I had left my umbrella at work.

exercises.question: Match the cleft structure to what it emphasizes.
exercises.hint: Cleft sentences 'cleave' the sentence in two to highlight one part.
exercises.example_sentence: All I want is some peace and quiet.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Not until the very end did she understand the plot.'
exercises.answer: Not until the very end did she understand the plot.
exercises.hint: Inversion after 'Not until' at the start.
exercises.example_sentence: Not until the very end did she understand the plot of the movie.

exercises.question: ___ nor his friends knew about the surprise party.
exercises.answer: Neither he
exercises.example_sentence: Neither he nor his friends knew about the surprise party we planned.

exercises.question: Which sentence emphasizes the place?
options: It was in London that we first met.
London is where we first met.
What happened in London was we met.
exercises.answer: It was in London that we first met.
exercises.example_sentence: It was in London that we first met, back in 2015.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to emphasize the only thing desired.
exercises.answer: All I want for my birthday is a rest
exercises.example_sentence: All I want for my birthday is a rest from all this work.

exercises.question: Match the negative structures to their formal meanings.
exercises.example_sentence: By no means is this project finished yet.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'What happened was that the car broke down in the middle of the road.'
exercises.answer: What happened was that the car broke down in the middle of the road.
exercises.hint: Focusing on the event using a Wh-cleft.
exercises.example_sentence: What happened was that the car broke down in the middle of the road.

exercises.question: ___ do we see such incredible talent in a young artist.
exercises.answer: Rarely
exercises.example_sentence: Rarely do we see such incredible talent in a young artist.

exercises.question: Choose the correct phrase: 'He didn't say a word...'
options: Nor did he look at me.
Neither he did look at me.
exercises.answer: Nor did he look at me.
exercises.example_sentence: He didn't say a word, nor did he look at me as I walked past.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to emphasize the reason.
exercises.answer: The reason why I'm late is that the traffic was bad
exercises.example_sentence: The reason why I'm late is that the traffic was exceptionally bad today.

exercises.question: Match the starting phrase with the correct continuation.
exercises.example_sentence: No sooner had I arrived than the phone rang.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'It was for this reason that we decided to cancel the trip.'
exercises.answer: It was for this reason that we decided to cancel the trip.
exercises.hint: Cleft sentence for emphasizing a reason.
exercises.example_sentence: It was for this reason that we decided to cancel the trip.

exercises.question: ___ she said made everyone in the room laugh.
exercises.answer: What
exercises.hint: Cleft sentence focusing on the content of speech.
exercises.example_sentence: What she said made everyone in the room laugh immediately.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses 'not only' with correct inversion?
options: Not only was it cold, but it was also raining.
Not only it was cold, but it was also raining.
Not only was it cold, it also was raining.
exercises.answer: Not only was it cold, but it was also raining.
exercises.example_sentence: Not only was it cold, but it was also raining heavily.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use a pseudo-cleft for an action.
exercises.answer: What he did was call the police immediately
exercises.example_sentence: What he did was call the police immediately after the accident.

exercises.question: ___ once did he complain about the difficult working conditions.
exercises.answer: Not
exercises.example_sentence: Not once did he complain about the difficult working conditions.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Little did I know that my life was about to change forever.'
exercises.answer: Little did I know that my life was about to change forever.
exercises.example_sentence: Little did I know that my life was about to change forever that day.

exercises.question: The more you practice your English, ___ your confidence will become.
exercises.answer: the greater
exercises.hint: Parallel comparative structure (The + comparative, the + comparative).
exercises.example_sentence: The more you practice your English, the greater your confidence will become.

exercises.question: Choose the correct phrase for a large difference: 'This phone is...'
options: nowhere near as expensive as that one.
not quite as expensive as that one.
just as expensive as that one.
exercises.answer: nowhere near as expensive as that one.
exercises.hint: Nowhere near as... as = a huge difference.
exercises.example_sentence: This phone is nowhere near as expensive as that one, despite having better features.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence about a specific reaction.
exercises.answer: There was a strong reaction to the proposal
exercises.example_sentence: There was a strong reaction to the proposal from the local community.

exercises.question: Match the nouns with their dependent prepositions.
exercises.hint: Focus on the preposition that follows the noun.
exercises.example_sentence: The solution to the problem was simpler than we thought.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The higher the temperature, the faster the chemical reaction.'
exercises.answer: The higher the temperature, the faster the chemical reaction.
exercises.hint: Maintain a rhythmic pace for parallel comparatives.
exercises.example_sentence: The higher the temperature, the faster the chemical reaction occurs.

exercises.question: The new model is ___ better than the old one.
exercises.answer: significantly
exercises.hint: Adverb used to modify a comparative adjective.
exercises.example_sentence: The new model is significantly better than the old one in terms of battery life.

exercises.question: Which sentence expresses that two things are almost the same?
options: The results are much the same as last year.
The results are nothing like last year.
The results are by far the same as last year.
exercises.answer: The results are much the same as last year.
exercises.hint: Much the same as = almost identical.
exercises.example_sentence: The results of the survey are much the same as last year.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use 'by far'.
exercises.answer: She is by far the most intelligent student
exercises.example_sentence: She is by far the most intelligent student in the entire class.

exercises.question: Match the comparative modifiers with their intensity.
exercises.example_sentence: He earns a great deal more than he used to.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'There has been a sharp fall in the number of unemployed people.'
exercises.answer: There has been a sharp fall in the number of unemployed people.
exercises.example_sentence: There has been a sharp fall in the number of unemployed people this month.

exercises.question: There is no doubt ___ the fact that climate change is real.
exercises.answer: about
exercises.example_sentence: There is no doubt about the fact that climate change is real.

exercises.question: Choose the correct phrase: 'He is...'
options: not nearly as tall as his father.
not near as tall as his father.
not nearly tall as his father.
exercises.answer: not nearly as tall as his father.
exercises.hint: Not nearly as... as = much less.
exercises.example_sentence: He is not nearly as tall as his father yet.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a proportional comparison.
exercises.answer: The house is twice as big as ours
exercises.example_sentence: Their new house is twice as big as ours.

exercises.question: Match the nouns for 'change' with the correct preposition.
exercises.example_sentence: The new law will have a significant impact on society.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The sooner we leave, the earlier we will arrive.'
exercises.answer: The sooner we leave, the earlier we will arrive.
exercises.example_sentence: The sooner we leave, the earlier we will arrive at our destination.

exercises.question: What is the reason ___ your delay?
exercises.answer: for
exercises.example_sentence: What is the reason for your delay this morning?

exercises.question: Which structure means 'getting more and more'?
exercises.answer: It's getting harder and harder.
exercises.example_sentence: It's getting harder and harder to find affordable housing.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use 'nothing like'.
exercises.answer: The weather here is nothing like at home
exercises.example_sentence: The weather here is nothing like the weather at home.

exercises.question: Do you have any experience ___ sales?
exercises.answer: in
exercises.example_sentence: Do you have any experience in sales or customer service?

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The more expensive the car, the higher the insurance costs.'
exercises.answer: The more expensive the car, the higher the insurance costs.
exercises.hint: The + comparative phrase + the + comparative phrase.
exercises.example_sentence: The more expensive the car, the higher the insurance costs tend to be.

exercises.question: Under no circumstances ___ you leave the building without permission.
exercises.answer: should
exercises.hint: Negative adverbial at the start requires inversion (Auxiliary + Subject).
exercises.example_sentence: Under no circumstances should you leave the building without permission.

exercises.question: Which phrasal verb means 'to tolerate'?
exercises.answer: Put up with
exercises.example_sentence: I don't know how you put up with that constant noise.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a formal inverted sentence.
exercises.answer: Seldom have I seen such a beautiful sunset
exercises.example_sentence: Seldom have I seen such a beautiful sunset in this part of the country.

exercises.question: Match the negative adverbials with the correct inversion structure.
exercises.hint: Pay attention to the auxiliary verb usage.
exercises.example_sentence: Little did he realize that the meeting had been cancelled.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I am really looking forward to meeting your family next week.'
exercises.answer: I am really looking forward to meeting your family next week.
exercises.example_sentence: I am really looking forward to meeting your family next week.

exercises.question: Rarely ___ such a talented musician perform in this small town.
exercises.answer: does
exercises.example_sentence: Rarely does such a talented musician perform in this small town.

exercises.question: Choose the correct phrasal verb: 'I need to...'
exercises.answer: cut down on sugar.
exercises.example_sentence: The doctor told me I need to cut down on sugar for my health.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence using 'on no account'.
exercises.answer: On no account must the door be left unlocked
exercises.example_sentence: On no account must the door be left unlocked overnight.

exercises.question: Match the 3-part phrasal verbs with their synonyms.
exercises.hint: Focus on the literal vs. figurative meanings.
exercises.example_sentence: I've always looked up to my older sister as a role model.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Not only did he arrive late, but he also forgot his notes.'
exercises.answer: Not only did he arrive late, but he also forgot his notes.
exercises.example_sentence: Not only did he arrive late, but he also forgot his notes.

exercises.question: Only after months of training ___ he feel ready for the marathon.
exercises.answer: did
exercises.hint: Inversion happens in the second clause after 'Only after...'.
exercises.example_sentence: Only after months of training did he feel ready for the marathon.

exercises.question: Which sentence is correct for 'meeting expectations'?
options: The movie didn't live up to my expectations.
The movie didn't live to my expectations.
The movie didn't live up my expectations.
exercises.answer: The movie didn't live up to my expectations.
exercises.example_sentence: The movie didn't quite live up to my expectations despite the good reviews.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express escaping a task.
exercises.answer: She tried to get out of doing the dishes
exercises.example_sentence: She tried to get out of doing the dishes by pretending to be tired.

exercises.question: Match the inversion trigger with its requirement.
exercises.example_sentence: Hardly had I finished lunch when the phone rang.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'We need to come up with a better solution to this problem.'
exercises.answer: We need to come up with a better solution to this problem.
exercises.hint: Come up with = to think of an idea.
exercises.example_sentence: We need to come up with a better solution to this problem quickly.

exercises.question: In no way ___ I mean to suggest that you were wrong.
exercises.answer: did
exercises.example_sentence: In no way did I mean to suggest that you were wrong.

exercises.question: Choose the correct phrase: 'I can't...'
options: keep up with all the new technology.
keep up all the new technology.
keep with all the new technology.
exercises.answer: keep up with all the new technology.
exercises.hint: To stay informed or at the same level.
exercises.example_sentence: It's difficult to keep up with all the new technology these days.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express disappointment.
exercises.answer: The performance fell short of what we expected
exercises.hint: Fell short of = did not reach the standard.
exercises.example_sentence: The performance fell short of what we expected from such a famous group.

exercises.question: ___ had we started our picnic when it began to pour with rain.
exercises.answer: Hardly
exercises.example_sentence: Hardly had we started our picnic when it began to pour with rain.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I've decided to go in for the local marathon this year.'
exercises.answer: I've decided to go in for the local marathon this year.
exercises.hint: Go in for = to enter a competition or have as an interest.
exercises.example_sentence: I've decided to go in for the local marathon this year.

exercises.question: It's high time you ___ for a job; you've been graduated for months.
exercises.answer: looked
exercises.hint: It's (high) time + subject + past simple (unreal past).
exercises.example_sentence: It's high time you looked for a job and started your career.

exercises.question: Which sentence expresses that an action was impossible in the past?
options: He couldn't have stolen the money; he was with me.
He mustn't have stolen the money; it's wrong.
He shouldn't have stolen the money.
exercises.answer: He couldn't have stolen the money; he was with me.
exercises.hint: Couldn't have + V3 for past impossibility.
exercises.example_sentence: He couldn't have stolen the money; he was with me the whole time.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a preference about someone else's behavior.
exercises.answer: I'd rather you didn't smoke in the house
exercises.example_sentence: I'd rather you didn't smoke in the house while the kids are here.

exercises.question: Match the modal perfects with their logical meanings.
exercises.hint: Focus on the level of certainty.
exercises.example_sentence: She must have forgotten our meeting; she's usually on time.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Suppose you had won the lottery, what would you have done?'
exercises.answer: Suppose you had won the lottery, what would you have done?
exercises.example_sentence: Suppose you had won the lottery, what would you have done with the money?

exercises.question: I'd rather ___ home tonight if you don't mind.
exercises.answer: stay
exercises.hint: I'd rather + base form (when there is no change of subject).
exercises.example_sentence: I'd rather stay home tonight and watch a movie than go out.

exercises.question: Choose the correct deduction: 'The ground is wet.'
options: It must have rained last night.
It should have rained last night.
It could have rained last night.
exercises.answer: It must have rained last night.
exercises.hint: Strong evidence for a past event.
exercises.example_sentence: The ground is wet; it must have rained last night.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a past regret using 'if only'.
exercises.answer: If only we hadn't lost the map in the forest
exercises.hint: If only + past perfect for past regret.
exercises.example_sentence: If only we hadn't lost the map in the forest, we would be home by now.

exercises.question: Match the 'I wish' structure to the correct time/meaning.
exercises.example_sentence: I wish I knew how to play the piano.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'They might have been delayed by the heavy traffic.'
exercises.answer: They might have been delayed by the heavy traffic.
exercises.example_sentence: They might have been delayed by the heavy traffic on the motorway.

exercises.question: Imagine you ___ an alien, what would you say to it?
exercises.answer: met
exercises.example_sentence: Imagine you met an alien, what would you say to it?

exercises.question: Which sentence means 'You didn't do it, but it was expected'?
options: You were to have finished by now.
You must have finished by now.
exercises.answer: You were to have finished by now.
exercises.hint: Be + to have + V3 describes unfulfilled plans.
exercises.example_sentence: You were to have finished the report by now, weren't you?

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence using 'as though'.
exercises.answer: He acts as though he were the boss
exercises.hint: As though/if + past (often using 'were' for all subjects).
exercises.example_sentence: He acts as though he were the boss, but he's just a junior employee.

exercises.question: Match the modal perfect with the speaker's attitude.

pairs.right: I went, but it wasn't necessary.
It wasn't necessary (maybe I didn't go).
I had the chance, but didn't go.
I wanted to go, but couldn't.

answer.right: I went, but it wasn't necessary.
It wasn't necessary (maybe I didn't go).
I had the chance, but didn't go.
I wanted to go, but couldn't.

exercises.hint: Subtle differences in past necessity and ability.
exercises.example_sentence: I needn't have brought my umbrella; it didn't rain at all.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I would rather you didn't mention this to anyone else.'
exercises.answer: I would rather you didn't mention this to anyone else.
exercises.example_sentence: I would rather you didn't mention this to anyone else for the time being.

exercises.question: She looks as if she ___ a ghost.
exercises.answer: had seen
exercises.hint: Use past perfect for something that looks like it happened earlier.
exercises.example_sentence: She looks as if she had seen a ghost; she's so pale.

exercises.question: What is the correct structure for 'It's time'?
options: It's time we to go home.
exercises.answer: It's time we went home.
exercises.example_sentence: It's getting late; it's time we went home.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express an unfulfilled past possibility.
exercises.answer: You could have called us and told where you were
exercises.hint: Expressing mild criticism for a past action not taken.
exercises.example_sentence: You could have called us and told us where you were!

exercises.question: I'd much rather ___ a movie than go to the theater.
exercises.answer: watch
exercises.example_sentence: I'd much rather watch a movie at home than go to the theater.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Had I known about the party, I would have definitely come.'
exercises.answer: Had I known about the party, I would have definitely come.
exercises.example_sentence: Had I known about the party, I would have definitely come.

exercises.question: ___ surprised me most was the sheer size of the building.
exercises.answer: What
exercises.hint: Noun clause acting as the subject.
exercises.example_sentence: What surprised me most was the sheer size of the building.

exercises.question: Choose the correct reporting structure: 'People believe he is living abroad.'
options: He is believed to be living abroad.
He is believed that he lives abroad.
It is believed him to live abroad.
exercises.answer: He is believed to be living abroad.
exercises.example_sentence: He is believed to be living abroad under a different name.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence about a perceived action.
exercises.answer: I saw him cross the street and enter the bank
exercises.hint: See someone + base form (for a completed action).
exercises.example_sentence: I saw him cross the street and enter the bank yesterday morning.

exercises.question: Match the 'sense verb' structures with their meanings.

pairs.right: I heard part of the song.

answer.right: I heard part of the song.

exercises.hint: Infinitive vs. Participle after verbs of perception.
exercises.example_sentence: I heard her singing in the shower as I walked by.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The fact that he didn't call is very strange.'
exercises.answer: The fact that he didn't call is very strange.
exercises.hint: The nominal clause is the subject here.
exercises.example_sentence: The fact that he didn't call is very strange, given he's usually so reliable.

exercises.question: It is ___ that the company will announce a merger soon.
exercises.answer: rumored
exercises.hint: Passive reporting: It + be + V3 + that...
exercises.example_sentence: It is rumored that the company will announce a merger soon.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses a nominal clause correctly as an object?
options: I don't know where she went.
I don't know where did she go.
I don't know where she go.
exercises.answer: I don't know where she went.
exercises.hint: No inversion in indirect questions/noun clauses.
exercises.example_sentence: I don't know where she went after the meeting ended.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to report a past state.
exercises.answer: The painting is said to have been stolen years ago
exercises.hint: To have + been + V3 for a past passive state.
exercises.example_sentence: The painting is said to have been stolen years ago from a private collection.

exercises.question: Match the passive reporting verbs with their common contexts.
exercises.example_sentence: The damage is estimated to be over a million dollars.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Whether we go or stay depends on the weather.'
exercises.answer: Whether we go or stay depends on the weather.
exercises.hint: A 'whether' clause acting as a subject.
exercises.example_sentence: Whether we go or stay depends on the weather tomorrow.

exercises.question: I felt the house ___ during the earthquake.
exercises.answer: shake
exercises.example_sentence: I felt the house shake during the earthquake last night.

exercises.question: Choose the formal equivalent: 'People think she is a genius.'
options: She is thought to be a genius.
She is thought she is a genius.
exercises.answer: She is thought to be a genius.
exercises.example_sentence: She is thought to be a genius in the field of mathematics.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence using 'It appears that'.
exercises.answer: It appears that the system has crashed again
exercises.example_sentence: It appears that the system has crashed again, so we'll have to restart.

exercises.question: Match the nominal clauses to their grammatical function.

pairs.right: Complement (The mystery is who she is).

answer.right: Complement (The mystery is who she is).

exercises.hint: Noun clauses can do anything a noun can do.
exercises.example_sentence: Whatever you want for dinner is fine with me.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'It is expected that hundreds of people will attend the protest.'
exercises.answer: It is expected that hundreds of people will attend the protest.
exercises.example_sentence: It is expected that hundreds of people will attend the protest tomorrow.

exercises.question: The suspect is alleged ___ the scene of the crime.
exercises.answer: to have fled
exercises.hint: Completed action in the past reported now.
exercises.example_sentence: The suspect is alleged to have fled the scene of the crime before police arrived.

exercises.question: Which sense verb structure describes a continuous action?
options: I watched the children playing in the park.
I watched the children play in the park.
I watched the children to play in the park.
exercises.answer: I watched the children playing in the park.
exercises.example_sentence: I watched the children playing in the park for a while.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use a nominal clause with 'How'.
exercises.answer: How he managed to escape is still not clear
exercises.hint: The whole 'How...' phrase is the subject.
exercises.example_sentence: How he managed to escape from the locked room is still not clear.

exercises.question: Everything ___ like roses in this garden.
exercises.answer: smells
exercises.hint: Stative use of a sense verb.
exercises.example_sentence: Everything smells so fresh in this garden after the rain.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'They are understood to have reached an agreement.'
exercises.answer: They are understood to have reached an agreement.
exercises.hint: Personal passive with a perfect infinitive.
exercises.example_sentence: They are understood to have reached an agreement after hours of negotiation.

exercises.question: ___ of the two candidates was suitable for the job.
exercises.answer: Neither
exercises.hint: Used for two people/things in a negative sense.
exercises.example_sentence: Neither of the two candidates was suitable for the job, so we re-advertised.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses ellipsis correctly to avoid repetition?
options: I went to the store and bought some milk.
I went to the store and I bought some milk.
I went to the store and then bought some milk later.
exercises.answer: I went to the store and bought some milk.
exercises.hint: Removing the subject 'I' because it's the same in both clauses.
exercises.example_sentence: I went to the store and bought some milk.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use a colon for a list.
exercises.answer: You need three things: courage, skill, and luck
exercises.hint: Colons introduce lists after a complete thought.
exercises.example_sentence: You need three things: courage, skill, and luck.

exercises.question: Match the quantifiers with their correct usage.

pairs.right: Focuses on a group as a whole.
Focuses on individual items in a group.
Used with plural or uncountable nouns.

answer.right: Focuses on a group as a whole.
Focuses on individual items in a group.
Used with plural or uncountable nouns.

exercises.hint: Distinction between collective and individual focus.
exercises.example_sentence: Every student passed, and each received a certificate.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I don't like horror movies; however, I loved this one.'
exercises.answer: I don't like horror movies; however, I loved this one.
exercises.example_sentence: I don't like horror movies; however, I loved this one.

exercises.question: He spent the ___ day sleeping.
exercises.answer: whole
exercises.example_sentence: He spent the whole day sleeping instead of studying.

exercises.question: Which word replaces the noun phrase to avoid repetition? 'I need a pen. Do you have...?'
exercises.answer: one?
exercises.hint: Substitution for a countable singular noun.
exercises.example_sentence: I need a pen. Do you have one I can borrow?

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use a semicolon between related clauses.
exercises.answer: The game was cancelled; it was raining heavily
exercises.hint: Semicolons link two independent but related clauses.
exercises.example_sentence: The game was cancelled; it was raining heavily.

exercises.question: Match the substitution words with what they replace.
exercises.example_sentence: If you want to leave, please do so quietly.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Each of the students has their own desk.'
exercises.answer: Each of the students has their own desk.
exercises.hint: Note that 'Each of' takes a singular verb 'has'.
exercises.example_sentence: Each of the students has their own desk in the classroom.

exercises.question: I asked them both, but ___ of them knew the answer.
exercises.answer: neither
exercises.example_sentence: I asked them both, but neither of them knew the answer.

exercises.question: How do you shorten: 'I hope that it won't rain'?
exercises.answer: I hope not.
exercises.hint: Substitution for a negative clause after 'hope'.
exercises.example_sentence: Will it rain today? I hope not.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use 'either... or'.
exercises.answer: You can either stay here or come with us
exercises.example_sentence: You can either stay here or come with us to the park.

exercises.question: Match the punctuation mark with its purpose.

pairs.right: Adds a sudden break or emphasis.

answer.right: Adds a sudden break or emphasis.

exercises.example_sentence: The store was closedI couldn't believe it!

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'All the furniture in this room is new.'
exercises.answer: All the furniture in this room is new.
exercises.example_sentence: All the furniture in this room is brand new.

exercises.question: Are you coming to the party? If ___, I'll see you there.
exercises.answer: so
exercises.hint: Substitution for the whole previous sentence.
exercises.example_sentence: Are you coming to the party? If so, I'll see you there.

exercises.question: Which is correct? 'I've read...'
options: I've read every book on this shelf.
I've read all book on this shelf.
I've read each books on this shelf.
exercises.answer: I've read every book on this shelf.
exercises.example_sentence: I've read every book on this shelf twice.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use a dash for emphasis.
exercises.answer: He finally won the racehis greatest achievement
exercises.hint: Use a dash to separate the extra information.
exercises.example_sentence: He finally won the racehis greatest achievement.

exercises.question: ___ of my friends live nearby.
exercises.answer: None
exercises.hint: Used for more than two people/things.
exercises.example_sentence: None of my friends live nearby anymore.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I'll have the green apples, not the red ones.'
exercises.answer: I'll have the green apples, not the red ones.
exercises.example_sentence: I'll have the green apples, not the red ones.

exercises.question: He denied ___ the window, even though everyone saw him.
exercises.answer: having broken
exercises.hint: Perfect gerund used to emphasize a past completed action.
exercises.example_sentence: He denied having broken the window, even though everyone saw him.

exercises.question: Which sentence expresses a wish about a past regret?
options: I wish I had studied harder for the exam.
I wish I studied harder for the exam.
I wish I would study harder for the exam.
exercises.answer: I wish I had studied harder for the exam.
exercises.example_sentence: I wish I had studied harder for the exam; I might have passed.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence about being bothered.
exercises.answer: I object to being treated like a child
exercises.example_sentence: I object to being treated like a child when I am clearly an adult.

exercises.question: Match the gerund/infinitive forms with their functions.
exercises.example_sentence: He complained about not having been told the truth.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I'd rather you had asked me before borrowing my car.'
exercises.answer: I'd rather you had asked me before borrowing my car.
exercises.hint: Past preference about someone else's past action.
exercises.example_sentence: I'd rather you had asked me before borrowing my car yesterday.

exercises.question: It's about time we ___ a decision on this matter.
exercises.answer: made
exercises.example_sentence: It's about time we made a decision on this matter.

exercises.question: Choose the correct perfect infinitive: 'He seems...'
exercises.answer: to have forgotten our meeting.
exercises.hint: Seems + perfect infinitive for a past action.
exercises.example_sentence: He seems to have forgotten our meeting again.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use a semicolon and a regret.
exercises.answer: I'm hungry; I wish I had eaten lunch
exercises.hint: Connecting a current state with a past regret.
exercises.example_sentence: I'm hungry; I wish I had eaten lunch earlier.

exercises.question: Match the 'Rather' structures with their meanings.
exercises.hint: Pay attention to the shifts in tense.
exercises.example_sentence: I'd rather have stayed at home than gone to that loud party.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'She was proud of having been selected for the team.'
exercises.answer: She was proud of having been selected for the team.
exercises.example_sentence: She was proud of having been selected for the national team.

exercises.question: If only I ___ where he was now.
exercises.answer: knew
exercises.hint: If only + past simple for a present wish.
exercises.example_sentence: If only I knew where he was now, I could help him.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses the perfect passive infinitive correctly?
options: The task was supposed to have been completed by Friday.
The task was supposed to have completed by Friday.
The task was supposed to being completed by Friday.
exercises.answer: The task was supposed to have been completed by Friday.
exercises.hint: Something that should have happened to the object.
exercises.example_sentence: The task was supposed to have been completed by Friday.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to express a past preference.
exercises.answer: I would rather have stayed at home instead
exercises.example_sentence: I would rather have stayed at home instead of going out in the rain.

exercises.question: Match the phrases with the correct following form.
exercises.hint: Grammar patterns for preferences and regrets.
exercises.example_sentence: I regret telling him my secret.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I wish you wouldn't keep interrupting me!'
exercises.answer: I wish you wouldn't keep interrupting me!
exercises.example_sentence: I wish you wouldn't keep interrupting me while I'm speaking!

exercises.question: I don't recall ___ to that meeting.
exercises.answer: having been invited
exercises.example_sentence: I don't recall having been invited to that meeting.

exercises.question: Choose the correct use of 'dash' for a sudden thought.
options: I was going to call himbut I forgot.
I was going to call him; but I forgot.
I was going to call him: but I forgot.
exercises.answer: I was going to call himbut I forgot.
exercises.hint: The dash represents a break in thought.
exercises.example_sentence: I was going to call himbut I forgot his number.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence using 'having'.
exercises.answer: Having finished all the work, we went home
exercises.hint: Participial clause replacing 'After we had finished...'.
exercises.example_sentence: Having finished all the work, we went home early.

exercises.question: The suspect admitted ___ the money.
exercises.answer: to having stolen
exercises.example_sentence: The suspect admitted to having stolen the money from the safe.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'They appeared to have been working through the night.'
exercises.answer: They appeared to have been working through the night.
exercises.example_sentence: They appeared to have been working through the night to meet the deadline.

exercises.question: ___, I didn't expect the project to be this successful.
exercises.answer: Admittedly
exercises.hint: Used to confess or acknowledge something is true.
exercises.example_sentence: Admittedly, I didn't expect the project to be this successful given the budget.

exercises.question: Which discourse marker signals a summary or general statement?
exercises.answer: By and large
exercises.hint: Means 'for the most part' or 'generally speaking'.
exercises.example_sentence: By and large, the new regulations have been welcomed by the staff.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence showing irony.
exercises.answer: Ironically, it was the sunniest day of the year
exercises.hint: Used when something happens in a way opposite to what is expected.
exercises.example_sentence: Ironically, it was the sunniest day of the year when we decided to stay indoors.

exercises.question: Match the discourse markers with their purpose.
exercises.hint: Focus on the logic of the connection.
exercises.example_sentence: The hotel was cheap. Mind you, it was very clean.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Broadly speaking, the economy is showing signs of recovery.'
exercises.answer: Broadly speaking, the economy is showing signs of recovery.
exercises.example_sentence: Broadly speaking, the economy is showing signs of recovery this quarter.

exercises.question: Will you be late? I hope ___.
exercises.answer: not
exercises.hint: Substitution for a negative clause after 'hope'.
exercises.example_sentence: Will you be late for the dinner? I hope not.

exercises.question: Choose the best substitution: 'If you want to complain, you should...'
exercises.answer: do so in writing.
exercises.hint: 'Do so' replaces a verb phrase formally.
exercises.example_sentence: If you wish to cancel your subscription, please do so in writing.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use a semicolon and 'consequently'.
exercises.answer: I was late; consequently, I missed the train
exercises.example_sentence: I was late; consequently, I missed the train to the city.

exercises.question: Match the adverbs with the attitude they express.
exercises.hint: These adverbs comment on the whole sentence.
exercises.example_sentence: Regrettably, the flight has been cancelled due to fog.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'He is a great athlete; moreover, he is a brilliant student.'
exercises.answer: He is a great athlete; moreover, he is a brilliant student.
exercises.hint: Pause slightly at the semicolon and the comma.
exercises.example_sentence: He is a great athlete; moreover, he is a brilliant student.

exercises.question: I don't like horror movies. ___, I find them quite boring.
exercises.answer: Indeed
exercises.hint: Used to add information that supports or confirms a previous statement.
exercises.example_sentence: I don't like horror movies. Indeed, I find them quite boring.

exercises.question: Which sentence uses 'if so' correctly?
options: Is it raining? If so, we'll stay home.
Is it raining? If so raining, we'll stay home.
Is it raining? If so it is, we'll stay home.
exercises.answer: Is it raining? If so, we'll stay home.
exercises.example_sentence: Is it raining? If so, we'll stay home and play cards.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use 'on the contrary'.
exercises.answer: He isn't lazy; on the contrary, he works very hard
exercises.hint: Used to show that the opposite is true.
exercises.example_sentence: He isn't lazy; on the contrary, he works very hard every day.

exercises.question: Match the formal discourse marker with its simpler equivalent.
exercises.example_sentence: To put it simply, we need more money.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Ironically, the fire station burned down.'
exercises.answer: Ironically, the fire station burned down.
exercises.hint: Focus on the 'i' sound in Ironically /arnkli/.
exercises.example_sentence: Ironically, the fire station burned down last night.

exercises.question: I haven't seen the film, but my brother ___.
exercises.answer: has
exercises.example_sentence: I haven't seen the film, but my brother has.

exercises.question: Choose the correct phrase: 'You must pay the fine;...'
options: otherwise, you will go to court.
unless, you will go to court.
or else, you will go to court.
exercises.answer: otherwise, you will go to court.
exercises.hint: 'Otherwise' shows the result if the condition isn't met.
exercises.example_sentence: You must pay the fine; otherwise, you will go to court.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence using 'As far as... is concerned'.
exercises.answer: As far as I'm concerned, this is completely wrong
exercises.hint: Used to introduce your personal opinion.
exercises.example_sentence: As far as I'm concerned, this is completely wrong.

exercises.question: He's very talented. ___, he's a bit arrogant.
exercises.answer: Even so
exercises.example_sentence: He's very talented. Even so, he's a bit arrogant at times.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Presumably, they'll be arriving late because of the strike.'
exercises.answer: Presumably, they'll be arriving late because of the strike.
exercises.hint: A logical guess based on evidence.
exercises.example_sentence: Presumably, they'll be arriving late because of the strike.

exercises.question: If I ___ so much coffee this morning, I wouldn't feel so jittery now.
exercises.answer: hadn't drunk
exercises.hint: Mixed conditional: Past action (3rd) affecting present state (2nd).
exercises.example_sentence: If I hadn't drunk so much coffee this morning, I wouldn't feel so jittery now.

exercises.question: Which sentence is correctly inverted for emphasis?
options: Not only did she win the race, but she also broke the record.
Not only she won the race, but she also broke the record.
Not only she did win the race, but she also broke the record.
exercises.answer: Not only did she win the race, but she also broke the record.
exercises.hint: Negative adverbial 'Not only' triggers auxiliary + subject inversion.
exercises.example_sentence: Not only did she win the race, but she also broke the record.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence about an unfulfilled plan.
exercises.answer: The project was to have been completed yesterday
exercises.hint: Was/Were to have + V3 describes a past plan that didn't happen.
exercises.example_sentence: The project was to have been completed yesterday, but there was a delay.

exercises.question: Match the advanced structures with their meanings.

pairs.right: I want you to go now.
If you happen to need help.

answer.right: I want you to go now.
If you happen to need help.

exercises.hint: Focus on formal alternatives to 'If' and 'Although'.
exercises.example_sentence: Should you need any further assistance, please contact us.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'No sooner had we arrived than the fireworks started.'
exercises.answer: No sooner had we arrived than the fireworks started.
exercises.hint: Use a rhythmic stress on 'No sooner' and 'than'.
exercises.example_sentence: No sooner had we arrived than the fireworks started.

exercises.question: He is thought ___ a fortune in the stock market last year.
exercises.answer: to have made
exercises.hint: Personal passive reporting a past action.
exercises.example_sentence: He is thought to have made a fortune in the stock market last year.

exercises.question: Identify the most formal way to express a condition:
options: Were they to offer me the job, I would accept it.
If they would offer me the job, I would accept it.
If they will offer me the job, I would accept it.
exercises.answer: Were they to offer me the job, I would accept it.
exercises.example_sentence: Were they to offer me the job, I would accept it immediately.

exercises.question: Reorder the words to use a semicolon and 'on the other hand'.
exercises.answer: He's very smart; on the other hand, he is lazy
exercises.example_sentence: He's very smart; on the other hand, he is quite lazy.

exercises.question: Match the phrasal verbs with their B2 synonyms.
exercises.example_sentence: The new policy will bring about significant changes.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'I'd rather you hadn't told her my secret; now everyone knows.'
exercises.answer: I'd rather you hadn't told her my secret; now everyone knows.
exercises.hint: Past preference for another person's action.
exercises.example_sentence: I'd rather you hadn't told her my secret; now everyone knows.

exercises.question: Little ___ we know that the surprise party was actually for us.
exercises.answer: did
exercises.hint: Inversion after 'Little' to show lack of knowledge.
exercises.example_sentence: Little did we know that the surprise party was actually for us!

exercises.question: Which sentence uses 'as though' to show a hypothetical present?
options: He talks as though he were an expert on everything.
He talks as though he is an expert on everything.
He talks as though he would be an expert.
exercises.answer: He talks as though he were an expert on everything.
exercises.hint: Use 'were' (subjunctive) for things that aren't true.
exercises.example_sentence: He talks as though he were an expert on everything, but he's just a beginner.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence using 'by far'.
exercises.answer: This is by far the worst movie I've ever seen
exercises.hint: Use 'by far' to emphasize a superlative.
exercises.example_sentence: This is by far the worst movie I've ever seen in my life.

exercises.question: Match the connectors with their logic.
exercises.example_sentence: You can go out provided that you finish your homework.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'Suppose you had the chance to travel in time, where would you go?'
exercises.answer: Suppose you had the chance to travel in time, where would you go?
exercises.example_sentence: Suppose you had the chance to travel in time, where would you go?

exercises.question: It's high time we ___ leaving; it's nearly midnight.
exercises.answer: were
exercises.hint: It's time + subject + past simple (here 'were leaving' for progress).
exercises.example_sentence: It's high time we were leaving; it's nearly midnight.

exercises.question: Choose the correct phrase: 'I'm used to...'
exercises.answer: getting up early now.
exercises.example_sentence: I'm used to getting up early now that I have a new job.

exercises.question: Reorder the words for a sentence using 'whatever'.
exercises.answer: Whatever he says, it must be true
exercises.hint: A relative clause acting as a concession.
exercises.example_sentence: Whatever he says, it must be true; he never lies.

exercises.question: I haven't been to Paris, and ___ has she.
exercises.answer: neither
exercises.example_sentence: I haven't been to Paris, and neither has she.

exercises.question: Pronounce: 'The more you know, the more you realize you don't know.'
exercises.answer: The more you know, the more you realize you don't know.
exercises.example_sentence: The more you know, the more you realize you don't know.
